quizTitle: O-Level Pure Chemistry: Electrolysis of Salts
instructions: Answer all electrolysis questions. Consider inert electrodes unless specified.

questions.question: What is produced at the cathode during electrolysis of molten sodium chloride (NaCl)?
options: Sodium metal
Chlorine gas
Hydrogen gas
Oxygen gas
questions.explanation: Molten NaCl: Na⁺ ions migrate to cathode, gain electrons → Na(l). Cl⁻ ions to anode → Cl₂(g).

questions.question: During electrolysis of dilute aqueous sodium chloride (NaCl) using inert electrodes, what forms at the anode?
options: Chlorine gas
Oxygen gas
Hydrogen gas
Sodium metal
questions.explanation: Aqueous NaCl: OH⁻ and Cl⁻ go to anode. OH⁻ discharged preferentially (dilute) → oxygen gas. Chlorine forms only with concentrated solution.

questions.question: Electrolysis of molten lead(II) bromide (PbBr₂) produces:
options: Lead at cathode, bromine at anode
Bromine at cathode, lead at anode
Hydrogen at cathode, oxygen at anode
Lead and bromine both at anode
questions.explanation: Molten PbBr₂: Pb²⁺ reduced at cathode → Pb(l). Br⁻ oxidised at anode → Br₂(g).

questions.question: Why is aluminium extracted by electrolysis of molten alumina (Al₂O₃) and not aqueous solution?
options: Aluminium reacts with water
Al³⁺ ions are not discharged in aqueous solution
Aluminium is less reactive than hydrogen
Alumina is insoluble in water
questions.explanation: Aluminium is more reactive than hydrogen. In aqueous solution, H⁺ would be discharged instead of Al³⁺, so no Al forms. Molten state needed.

questions.question: Electrolysis of concentrated aqueous copper(II) chloride (CuCl₂) produces:
options: Copper at cathode, chlorine at anode
Hydrogen at cathode, oxygen at anode
Copper at anode, chlorine at cathode
Hydrogen at cathode, chlorine at anode
questions.explanation: Concentrated CuCl₂(aq): Cu²⁺ reduced at cathode → Cu(s). Cl⁻ oxidised at anode → Cl₂(g). No H⁺/OH⁻ discharged due to concentration and lower discharge potential of Cl⁻ over OH⁻ here.

questions.question: What is the key difference between electrolysis of molten salt and aqueous salt?
options: Aqueous involves water molecules that may be discharged
Molten salts conduct electricity better
Aqueous electrolysis always produces hydrogen and oxygen
Molten salts require higher voltage
questions.explanation: In aqueous solutions, H⁺ and OH⁻ ions from water are present and may be discharged depending on concentration and position in electrochemical series.
